title: Before 1 October 2019, will nuclear experts from the IAEA, the CTBTO, the UN, United States, or South Korea visit North Korea’s Yongbyon nuclear facility?
preds:
I see no reason why they should be let in at this time.
https://news.un.org/en/story/2019/03/1034041
No. But in principle, lets leave a change for something odd.
late to the party here.... I almost feel guilty....  it was unlikely a while back but this late in the game I can't see it happening
Progress in NK seems to have stalled again, so I think it's very unlikely that outsiders will be allowed in to view any sensitive facilities in the short term.
The chance that North Korea (or the USA) accepts at this point is low.
Only one month to go. Considering the fate of the Iran nuclear deal, North Korea is less likely to agree to a deal.
They may try, but I dont think they will be allowed in
I do not feel as if the current political climate in North Korea would accept this at trhis time
Short window of time, and there are  more distracting and pressing activities going on in the world that are taking governments' attention
Not enough time or political will for successful negotiations
He will not allow because there is something he is concealing from the world.

Lowering based on crowd and arguments in:
 https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/853282
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/840532
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/830818
For what reason would Kim Jong Un have for allowing nuclear experts to come visit?
He feels at least a little bit negotiable so I don't think it's entirely impossible.
The focus is elsewhere in the world.

Passage of time. NK threatens to restart nuclear tests if the planned August 2019 US - SK military drills take place.
http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/1158143.shtml
Reconsidering, just dont think the logistics are there—especially given the current activity going on at Yongbyon

Unlikely, given the time frame. Although radical action is not impossible given the weirdness of this diplomatic relationship. Although, even then the logistics and hashing out of details would push it past Oct 1 (nichodges comment supports this)

10 weeks out, it seems that even if international diplomacy was in a good state, the logistics would not be possible within the timeframe.
For context of the timing - when Yongbyon was inspected by the IAEA in 2007 the agreement was reached on 13 Feb and inspectors arrived on June 28.
N. Korea gains nothing by allowing a visit
What for, now that he is President Trump's best friend?

Kim Jong un always going to be a dictator. United Nation's peace, harmony  among nations is good for Kim Jong Un till he isn't in trouble. Once he stuck between those stuff, there are more chances he can also oppose United Nation too.

I can't find anything on plans to visit Yongbyon from any of the above orgs, it seems that tabs are kept on Yongbyon via satellite intelligence. Some journalists were allowed in but they were not able to bring in any equipment (taken at airport).  https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-47397699
https://ewn.co.za/2019/06/11/nuclear-stalemate-one-year-after-trump-kim-summit-analysts
N. Korea isn't interested in a real agreement - they think they can manipulate Trump into a sweet deal for them that they would not have to honor. They won't allow inspectors in.
If a deal is made in writing. But i dont see thqt happeneing
The current return to a colder relationship between NK and the west is unlikely to promote such a visit.
North Korea will keep its nuculear capabability as a bargaining chip for as long as possible, so its unlikely a visit will happen anytime soon.
I have a better chance at winning the Mr. Olympia contest.
Unlikely visit to be scheduled so fast

It is unlikely that there will a visit to North Korea's nuclear facility due to a couple of reasons. First of all, Kim Jung-Un will not let any inspections take place without an agreement, which also seems unlikely. Secondly, the rise of tensions in the region make it too dangerous for inspections. However, there is that slight possibility that an inspection will occur. After all is said and done, there is unlikely to be a visit to North Korea's nuclear facility for it is dangerous and will not happen. Source:
- https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/why-the-trump-kim-nuclear-show-is-set-for-act-iii/2019/04/15/afcb0d16-5ff8-11e9-bf24-db4b9fb62aa2_story.html?utm_term=.1f9a2e1b94e8

Haha. Not with Trump as president. Trump loves hype. The process leading to nuclear inspections requires hard diplomacy & is not sexy. Trump has already achieved the same "result" with his off-the-wall declarations. Why put up the hard work to achieve something that Trump can simply announce has been achieved without relying on the facts?
Kim is playing us here in the US. I see no evidence of any real movement. This is highly unlikley.
US won't let up on sanctions, Kim will not make concessions.
Doesn't seem to be in Kim's MO - he will want concessions others can't give
Little chance this can be successfully negotiated by then
I don't believe it's time yet.

As a retired scientist whose career dealt with arms control and minimizing threats from weapons of mass destruction, I have followed the DPRK situation for years.  Recent satellite imagery analyzed by groups like 38north.org seems to show renewed nuclear enrichment.  I'd be very surprised if they reverse that in the next 6 months.
This is unlikely given North Korea’s history and ambitions.

Lower forecast on rethinking this.  Helpful thoughts and information from @nonplus [1] and @D_L_Parks [2] [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/840532
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/830818

Should N. Korea's attempts at supplying themselves with food fail, then logically a U.N. visit may be the only viable option. The Yongbyon facility is well known, but it is not the only facility N.K. owns.

The DPRK is maneuvering and is not taking serious steps to halt its weapons program. It will not give the Trump administration a free victory, and Trump is unwilling to make concessions without reaching an agreement with China.
The DPRK will not reveal military secrets at a time of growing conflict.

No. There is likely to be some event that stalls this strange course for peace. Contrary to common thinking this is not a fast track to integration for normalization. In theoretical notions, that talks are better than isolation, Dems generally to hold true but in this weird circumstance that could turn out to be naive. Motives can meet and forge strong bonds when both are seeking a way to begin, but to sustain peace there needs to be a shared, mutual outcome and not just posturing for advantage. Something vital is missing in the current process. It’s all show and no go.
North Korea is unlikely to surrender its nuclear capability.
Kim Jong Un won’t relinquish what he feels gives him power.
This is a sensible issue for NK, but they are under pressure, so there is room for some small probability it happens.

I do not feel that Supreme Leader will allow this.  He is very protective of this program.  If he were to allow an inspection before getting significant back down, sanctions removed and economic/political booms from the US at this point he will appear weak and lose face.
do not see any positive signs, indications - or wishes from the North - that such a visit will happen.  too much a stake for all stakeholders
Especially if the US puts something on the table
Does not serve Kim's negotiating position
Un may talk about this but it is very unlikely that he will allow it, especially since satellite images seem to indicate building and other activity at the nuclear site.
Not yet. Possibly in a year or 2. Wouldn’t bet my house on it though. Both Trump and Kim are loose cannons and literally, ANYTHING can happen with those two at the helm. Might even get peace......
First money, and after that visits.
It doesn't serve NK's short term interests to allow inspections at this time
Insufficient progress on discussions between Trump and Kim
There is virtually no possibility of this happening before October 1st, 2019 given current geopolitical conditions.
Not happening, no progress being made. Long way off from that.

There has been no real dialogue that shows any real warming between North Korea and the West.  With increased tensions between US and China, there is no way to have pressure from the biggest trading partner to force their hand.

North Korea is in the driver's seat and has not been successfully challenged by the Trump Administration with severe consequences.  Kim Jung Un's hand must be forced militarily if any progress on nuclear disarmament is to occur.
Nothing suggests North Korea is really sanxious to share,

Base rate: From what I can tell it has been visited twice: once in 2007 by the IAEA and once in 2010 by the USA [2]. Since the start of its operation in 1986, this gives a base rate of ~6%. Given that there only ~6 months left, this is reduced to ~3%. The Hanoi incident [3] leads adjust downward, but then again Pompeo says there will be another summit [4]. Overall, this leads me to estimate 2%. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yongbyon_Nuclear_Scientific_Research_Center
[2] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_power_in_North_Korea#Indigenous_light_water_reactor_development
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-usa-denuclearisation-yongb/explainer-north-koreas-yongbyon-nuclear-complex-takes-center-stage-in-stalled-talks-idUSKCN1QI3KL
[4] https://www.politico.com/story/2019/04/05/mike-pompeo-north-korea-summit-1259312

Visiting is not a fundamental issue and it can be realized with little difficulties.
Chairman Xi of PRC will visit Pyongyang at October.
Visit can be made before Xi's visit to Pyongyang.

Unlikely. Who’s he going to impress with everything held together via duct tape? He knows element of surprise/limited info better serves his purposes. USA has good idea of what’s going on via their intel (better than often revealed).

Kim may not be able to resist the opportunity to show off his nation's nuclear prowess. He would certainly enjoy embarrassing Trump, after having duped him into believing that North Korea was deescalating its nuclear program.
If intel suggesting that the nuclear program continues, no way that North Korea allows in inspectors.
As with Kim's visit to Seoul, this is unlikely to occur before 2020, mainly because that will provide greater benefit to Donald Trump in his re-election campaign.

North Korea may break off US talks and resume missile tests, official says
https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-47578451
Dropping to zero because, well you know, the Hanoi thing.

With the recent collapse of the Trump-Kim summit, it is clear that Kim is not willing to give in to the US's demand for denuclearization without substantial concessions from the US.  Trump cannot afford to appear giving in to Kim.  So here we have it, a standoff.  So long as Kim does not perform future nuclear and missile tests, but you never know, the status quote will stand, and therefore nothing happens.

Baseline, just living door open. Nukes are Kim's insurance policy, it is unlikely he will get rid of them.
https://www.economist.com/asia/2019/02/28/donald-trump-and-kim-jong-un-leave-vietnam-without-a-deal
Failure of Kim-Trump meeting. Unless Trump can bring bigger carrots, no deal. The Master of the Art of the Deal should know that.

Starting with a baseline of 4% because it has been over 10 years since the site was last inspected. According to SECSTATE, nuclear negotiations will continue despite the outcome of the most recent summit,[1] but I will need to see concrete steps forward before raising my probability. [1] https://www.apnews.com/895b46cb1af74dca99af3a32faa3723b

I think it likely because the optics are good, and what new information would a visit add. Perversely, I think a refusal to allow a visit would send a message NKs facilities are less advanced than they would have us think.

It's not entirely clear if Kim is thinking of closing all of it, or just part, or how long that will take. It's also not clear what parts of it might be opened to inspectors, or for how long. Or, for that matter, who those inspectors might be. When Kim decided to close the North's underground nuclear testing facility in Punggye-ri, he allowed only foreign media in to watch. They got quite the display of explosions and billowing clouds of smoke, similar to the demolition of the Yongbyon cooling tower years before.
http://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/AJ201902220051.html

This feels like the sort of concession that Kim may offer and then delay endlessly. I don't see what the North Koreans get out of having a visit so I'm not really sure why they would actually go through with one.
This question is asking if Kim wants to cut his own throat. NUTS.
